profileText: A Representative from Pennsylvania; born in Philadelphia, Pa., August 28, 1755; attended the Friends schools; was graduated from the medical department of the University of Pennsylvania at Philadelphia in 1780 and practiced in that city; was also an apothecary; served in the Revolutionary War; was a fellow of the College of Physicians of Philadelphia, of which he was one of the founders in 1787, and was treasurer from 1791 to 1809; member of the Pennsylvania Prison Society and president of the Pennsylvania Humane Society; elected as a Republican to the Tenth Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Joseph Clay; reelected to the Eleventh Congress and served from November 16, 1808, until his resignation in June 1809; died in Philadelphia, Pa., April 23, 1813.

note.content: Elected to fill vacancy caused by resignation of Joseph Clay, and took his seat November 16, 1808.
One of three elected to represent 1st district.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Say, Benjamin. An annual oration pronounced before the Humane Society of Philadelphia on the objects & benefits of said institution, the 28th day of February 1799. Whitehall, [Pa.]: Printed for William Young ..., 1799.

researchRecord.name: 1785-1804, 1 volume.
researchRecord.description: The account book of Dr. Benjamin Say, guardian of the estate of John Bird, executor of the estate of Thomas Say, and guardian of the children of Cornelius Barnes.

researchRecord.name: In the Henry Pleasants Collection, 1693-1825, 3 volumes.
1796-1804, 1 ledger.
researchRecord.description: A ledger contains accounts with Benjamin Say's patients for attendance and medicines. Also included is a list of Say's memberships and degrees; pasted on following page, a manuscript copy of his letter, July 17, 1801, declining to run for a second term in the Pennsylvania Senate.
